choices.text: Circulating antibodies directed against factor VIII
Decreased hepatic synthesis of multiple coagulation factors
Genetic defect involving the factor VIII gene

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of right flank pain, which developed after he helped his father paint the ceiling of his bedroom. Physical examination demonstrates an area of ecchymosis in the right flank that is tender to palpation. The patient has a lifelong history of easy bruising. His brother shows the same tendency. The serum level of clotting factor VIII is less than 2% of normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for bleeding tendency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder of blood clotting that results in spontaneous bleeding, particularly into joints, muscles, and internal organs.
  • Classic hemophilia results from mutations in the gene encoding factor VIII (hemophilia A). Hemophilia A is the most frequently encountered sex-linked inherited bleeding disorder (1 per 5,000 to 10,000 males).
  • Severe hemophilia is defined by <1-2% activity of factor VIII, leading to spontaneous bleeding, hemarthroses, and soft tissue hemorrhages (as seen here).
  • It can cause prolongation of APTT and is treated with factor replacement therapy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Circulating antibodies directed against factor VIII(Option A):It is seen in acquired hemophilia, often in older adults, postpartum women, or autoimmune conditions. Not likely in a child with lifelong symptoms and family history.
  • Decreased hepatic synthesis of multiple coagulation factors(Option B):That would cause both PT and APTT to be prolonged, and usually presents in liver disease, not isolated factor VIII deficiency.
  • Deficiency of vitamin K(Option C): It affects factors II, VII, IX, and X, not factor VIII. Also more common in newborns, malnourished individuals, or those on antibiotics.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl develops widespread pinpoint skin hemorrhages. She recovered from a flu-like illness 1 week earlier. Laboratory findings reveal a platelet count of 20,000/mL but no other abnormalities. Her bone marrow shows an increased number of megakaryocytes. The platelet count is normal after 2 months. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the 9 year old has a history of viral fever and laboratory investigation showing an isolated thrombocytopenia, with an increased number of precursor megakaryocytes normalised within 2 months of time. This is suggestive of most probably Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • ITP is a quantitative disorder of platelets caused by antibodies directed against platelet or megakaryocytic antigens. Similar to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, the etiology of ITP is related to antibody-mediated immune destruction of platelets or their precursors.
  • In adults with acute ITP, the platelet count is typically less than 20,000/μL. In chronic adult ITP, the platelet count varies from a few thousand to 100,000/μL. The peripheral blood smear in ITP exhibits numerous large platelets, and the bone marrow shows a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes.
  • Acute ITP in children typically appears after a viral illness and presents with sudden onset of petechiae and purpura without other symptoms. Spontaneous recovery can be expected in more than 80% of cases within 6 months. Thrombocytopenia may be observed in the other choices but is usually associated with other systemic signs and symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS)(Option A): An autoimmune disorder associated with arterial/venous thrombosis and recurrent fetal loss. Often involves hypercoagulability, not bleeding due to thrombocytopenia alone.
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)(Option B): It involves consumptive coagulopathy → ↓ platelets, ↓ fibrinogen, ↑ D-dimer, ↑ PT/APTT.
  • Levels of fibrin degradation products, including crosslinked fibrin degradation products (D-dimer), are usually increased in the presence of acute venous thromboembolism.
  • Associated with sepsis, trauma, malignancy and can be acutely life-threatening.
  • Patient would have abnormal coagulation profile, not isolated thrombocytopenia
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)(Option C): It typically follows E. coli O157:H7 infection and shows a classic triad:
    1. Hemolytic anemia
    2. Thrombocytopenia
    3. Acute kidney injury

questions.text: Identify the defect in RBC morphology in the image given below ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given smear shows helmet cells with spiculated ends in a case of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
  • Schistocytes are fragmented red blood cells seen on a peripheral blood smear. They are a hallmark of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), where RBCs are physically sheared as they pass through small vessels with fibrin strands or damaged endothelium.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Sickle cell (Option A): These are crescent- or sickle-shaped RBCs seen in sickle cell anemia due to polymerization of HbS. They do not resemble the fragmented, irregular RBC fragments (schistocytes) seen here.

Bite cells (Option B): These RBCs appear as if a "bite" has been taken out of them, typically seen in G6PD deficiency due to removal of Heinz bodies by splenic macrophages. They differ from the jagged, fragmented schistocytes.

Elliptocytes (Option D): These are elongated, oval-shaped RBCs commonly seen in hereditary elliptocytosis and some anemias. They are smooth and oval, not irregular fragmented cells as in schistocytes.

questions.text: In an Endothelial injury a tissue factor is released. This tissue factor combines with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In case of endothelial injury, the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade is activated. The key trigger in this pathway is the release of Tissue Factor (TF), also known as Factor III, from damaged endothelial cells and surrounding tissues.
  • Tissue Factor (TF) is a transmembrane glycoprotein it binds with circulating Factor VII to forms theTF-Factor VIIa complex, which:
    • Activates Factor X to Xa
    • Also activates Factor IX to IX
    • This leads to thrombin generation and ultimately fibrin clot formation.

Explanation of other options:

  • vWF (von Willebrand Factor)(Option B): It binds to platelets and Factor VIII, and causes platelet adhesion, not initiation of the coagulation cascade.
  • Factor VIII(Option C): It functions in the intrinsic pathway with Factor IX, but not directly involved with tissue factor.
  • Factor XII(option D): Initiates the intrinsic pathway (contact activation), not the extrinsic pathway activated by tissue factor.

questions.text: Which clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Deficiency of Factor XII (Hageman factor) does not cause a bleeding tendency in vivo. It prolongs activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) in vitro.
  • Factor XII initiates the intrinsic pathway of coagulation in vitro but in the human body (in vivo), the extrinsic pathway (tissue factor pathway) is the primary initiator of coagulation, thus its deficiency does not cause abnormal bleeding.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Factor V (Option A): Deficiency of Factor V leads to a bleeding tendency since it is a crucial cofactor in the common pathway, helping prothrombin convert to thrombin. Its absence markedly impairs clotting in vivo.

Factor IX (Option B): Also known as Christmas factor, its deficiency causes Hemophilia B. This directly affects the intrinsic pathway and leads to defective clot formation in vivo.

Factor VII (Option C): This factor activates the extrinsic pathway. Deficiency results in impaired initiation of coagulation, prolonging PT and leading to bleeding manifestations in vivo.

questions.text: Rapid assessment of the entire coagulation pathway in an emergency?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Unlike traditional tests like prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), Thromboelastography(TEG) is viscoelastic test and assesses platelet function, clot strength, and fibrinolysis.

Measurement Parameters:

  • TEG evaluates several key parameters related to clot formation:
    • Reaction Time (R value): Represents the time until the first evidence of a clot is detected.
    • K value: Measures the time from the end of R until the clot reaches 20 mm, indicating the speed of clot formation.
    • Angle: Derived from the tangent of the curve as K is reached, offering similar information to K.
    • Maximum Amplitude (MA): Reflects clot strength.
    • Coagulation Index (CI): An overall assessment that combines the contributions of R, K, angle, and MA.
    • G-value: A log-derivation of MA, representing clot strength in dynes/sec units.
    • Clot Lysis: TEG also measures clot lysis, reported as estimated percent lysis (EPL) and the percentage of clot lysed after 30 minutes (LY30,%).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

PT (Option A): Prothrombin time assesses only the extrinsic and common pathways (Factors I, II, V, VII, X). It cannot give a rapid overview of the entire coagulation system.

CT (Option B): Clotting time is an older, crude test with poor sensitivity and reproducibility. It does not provide detailed or reliable information about all phases of coagulation.

APTT (Option C): Activated partial thromboplastin time assesses the intrinsic and common pathways (Factors I, II, V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII). Like PT, it does not evaluate the entire coagulation process.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented to the clinic with a history of recurrent infections. On examination the child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in the kid?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the 5 year old is presenting with eczema, Immunodeficiency with thrombocytopenia which is suggestive of most probably Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
  • This syndrome is an X-linked disorder.
  • Characteristics include eczema, thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and poor antibody response to polysaccharide antigens.
  • It is caused by mutations in the gene encoding Wiskott- Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), which is located at XP11.23. WASP is involved in cytoskeleton dependent responses including cell migration and signal transduction.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome Triad: (WA-TER)
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Eczema
    • Recurrent bacterial infections.

Explanation of other options:

  • Job Syndrome (Hyper-IgE Syndrome)(Option A): Its Features include eczema, recurrent staph infections, and elevated IgE, but normal platelets.
  • Henoch-Schonlein purpura (IgA vasculitis)(Option C): A small-vessel vasculitis, not an immunodeficiency. Presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement.
  • Bruton's agammaglobulinemia(Option D): It is an X-linked, but features recurrent bacterial infections due to absent B cells and low immunoglobulins, not eczema or thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following produces vWF?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • VWF is a large multimeric glycoprotein present in blood plasma and produced constitutively as ultra-large VWF in endothelium.
  • Von Willebrand Factor's primary function is binding to other proteins, in particular factor VIII, and it is important in platelet adhesion to wound sites. It is not an enzyme and, thus, has no catalytic activity.
  • Endothelial cells contain intracellular stores known as Weibel Palade Bodies which contain vWF and P-selectin. Functions of von Willebrand factor:
  • Prolongs the half-life of factor VIII by stabilizing it (halflife of Factor VIII - 2.4 hours when free and 12 hours when bound to vWF in the circulation).
  • Adhesion of platelets to subendothelium. vWF is produced by endothelial cells and to some extent by megakaryocytes. Ristocetin induces multivalent vWF multimer to bind platelet glycoprotein Ib-IX and forms interplatelet bridges. Von Willebrand disease - Most common inherited bleeding disorder of humans Type 1 and 3 are due to quantitative defects in vWF Type 2 is due to qualitative defects in vWF

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Platelets (Option B): Platelets store vWF in their α-granules and release it during activation, but they do not produce it. The primary site of synthesis is endothelial cells.

Neutrophils (Option C): These are white blood cells involved in innate immunity and defense against infections. They do not produce or store vWF.

Macrophages (Option D): These phagocytic immune cells clear debris and pathogens. They play no role in vWF production.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising since early childhood. His platelet count is normal, but bleeding time is prolonged. There is no family history of similar issues. Further testing reveals a platelet aggregation defect. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the child is having symptoms of nosebleed with normal platelet levels and a defective platelet aggregation which clearly points to Glanzmann's thrombasthenia (GT).
  • It is a genetic platelet surface receptor disorder of GPIIb/IIIa (ITG αIIbβ3), either qualitative or quantitative, which results in faulty platelet aggregation and diminished clot retraction.
  • Spontaneous mucocutaneous bleeding is common and can lead to fatal bleeding episodes. 

Explanation of other options:

  • Gp Ib-IX(Option B): It is seen as defective in Bernard-Soulier syndrome, which presents with thrombocytopenia and giant platelets. This glycoprotein is a receptor for vWF and is essential for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix
  • CD68(Option C): A macrophage marker.
  • Von Willebrand factor(Option D): It is defective in von Willebrand disease, which affects platelet adhesion, not aggregation.

questions.text: After tonsillectomy, a 9-year-old child is having continuous bleeding. Bleeding time and aPTT are prolonged. Platelet count and PT are normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the 9 year old patient presents with post operative bleeding, on investigation the platelet count seems normal but the bleeding time and aPTT are both prolonged suggestive of a defective intrinsic pathway of coagulation cascade, from the options its suggestive of von willebrand disease.
  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, Causes defective platelet adhesion due to ↓ or dysfunctional vWF
  • vWF causes adhesion of platelets to subendothelial collagen, primarily through the glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) platelet receptor.
  • Also causes prolonged PTT because vWF stabilizes Factor VIII (part of intrinsic pathway)
  • Normal platelet count and PT, but prolonged bleeding time and PTT
  • Commonly presented with mucocutaneous bleeding and post-surgical bleeding.

Explanation of other options:

  • Vitamin K deficiency(Option B): It causes prolonged PT and PTT, not bleeding time and affects Factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C/S.
  • Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)(OptionC): Patient lab work would show low platelet count, not prolonged PTT.

Hemophilia A(Option D): PTT prolonged, but bleeding time is normal, and bleeding is usually deep tissue or joints, not mucosal.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines Evans Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Evans syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the co-occurrence (simultaneous or sequential) of:
    • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) causing destruction of red blood cells
    • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) causing destruction of platelets

questions.text: Five years old child presents with oliguria. There is a history of bloody diarrhea 2 weeks ago. Coagulation tests are normal. Peripheral smear is given. What is your diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Features of oliguria following an episode of diarrhea with peripheral smear finding of Schistocytes (Helmet cells) is suggestive of Hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA), a group of disorders that includes both HUS and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
  • These conditions are characterized by the formation of thrombi in small vessels such as capillaries and arterioles, particularly in organs like the kidneys. The microvascular thrombi disrupts normal blood flow, leading to shearing of red blood cells (causing microangiopathic hemolytic anemia), platelet consumption (leading to thrombocytopenia), and organ dysfunction due to ischemia.
  • Typical HUS, also known as diarrhea-associated or Shiga toxin-mediated HUS, most commonly occurs in children after ingestion of food contaminated with Shiga toxin-producing coli or Shigella dysenteriae. This form of HUS usually follows a bout of bloody diarrhea and presents with signs of renal failure such as oliguria, along with anemia and low platelet count. The coagulation profile generally remains normal, helping to distinguish it from other thrombotic or bleeding disorders.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (Option A): TTP usually presents in adults with the pentad of fever, neurologic symptoms, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and renal impairment. It is not typically preceded by bloody diarrhea in children, which is more characteristic of HUS.

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (Option B): ITP is an autoimmune destruction of platelets leading to isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding. It does not cause hemolysis, schistocytes on smear, or renal involvement as seen in HUS.

G6PD deficiency (Option C): This causes hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., drugs, fava beans, infections). Peripheral smear shows bite cells and Heinz bodies, not schistocytes. Renal failure following bloody diarrhea is not a feature.

questions.text: A 10-day infant presented with large cephalohematoma. His parents gave no history of trauma but severe umbilical bleeding during his childbirth. What is the most likely factor deficiency associated?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the initial hemostasis is normal but the clot stabilisation is defective. This is suggestive of Factor XII deficiency.
  • Abnormal bleeding manifests shortly after birth, when bleeding from the healthy umbilical cord remnant occurs.
  • Umbilical stump bleeding is an uncommon presentation for other congenital bleeding disorders. Rebleeding at circumcision is also common.
  • The most life-threatening complication of factor XIII deficiency is spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

vWF (Option A): Von Willebrand factor deficiency leads to mucocutaneous bleeding and prolonged bleeding time due to defective platelet adhesion. It does not cause delayed bleeding such as persistent umbilical stump bleeding or large cephalohematomas in neonates.

Factor I deficiency (Option B): Also called afibrinogenemia, this rare disorder causes impaired fibrin clot formation. Patients present with prolonged PT and aPTT. In the question, coagulation screening tests are usually normal in Factor XIII deficiency, which helps differentiate.

Factor VIII deficiency (Option C): Seen in Hemophilia A, this causes hemarthrosis and deep tissue bleeding in males, but typically not umbilical stump bleeding at birth. PT is normal, but aPTT is prolonged, unlike Factor XIII deficiency where both are normal.

choices.text: If the platelet count cannot be maintained at >50,000/ mcL
In cases of central nervous system/gastrointestinal bleeding

questions.text: The following is not a contraindication for heparin in DIC?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Use of Heparin in DIC:

  • Low doses of continuous infusion heparin (5-10 U/ kg per h) may be effective in patients with low-grade DIC associated with solid tumor, acute promyelocytic leukemia, or in a setting with recognized thrombosis.
  • Heparin is also indicated for the treatment of purpura fulminans during the surgical resection of giant hemangiomas and during removal of a dead fetus.
  • In acute DIC, the use of heparin is likely to aggravate bleeding.
  • Heparin use is contraindicated if platelet count is severely low, as it increases bleeding risk.
  • Active bleeding in critical sites is a strong contraindication for anticoagulation due to the risk of catastrophic hemorrhage.
  • In obstetric DIC with active bleeding, heparin use is typically avoided.

choices.text: Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis
Factor V becomes resistant to cleavage by protein C

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Factor V Leiden mutation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited thrombophilia.
  • The mutation is a Guanine to Adenine substitution at nucleotide 1691 of the F5 gene, resulting in an amino acid change from Arginine (Arg or R) to Glutamine (Gln or Q) at position 506
  • Individuals with Factor V Leiden have an increased tendency for venous thromboembolism (VTE), particularly DVT. The risk is higher in homozygotes and those with additional risk factors (e.g., pregnancy, OCP use).
  • Factor V becomes resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C. As a result, an important antithrombotic counterregulatory pathway is lost and chances of thrombosis are highly raised

questions.text: Which of the following enhances the activity of antithrombin?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Antithrombin, a serine protease inhibitor, regulates coagulation by inactivating thrombin and other procoagulant enzymes, including factors Xa, IXa, XIa, and XIIa.
  • Once bound to Heparin,Heparin is a negatively charged glycosaminoglycan that significantly enhances the activity of antithrombin. It does so by inducing a conformational change in antithrombin, increasing its affinity for target clotting factors, especially thrombin and Factor Xa.
  • This accelerates the inhibition of coagulation, which is the basis of heparin's clinical use as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a usual cause of DVT?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) most commonly occurs due to factors described in Virchow's Triad:
    • Endothelial injury - e.g., surgery, trauma, infection(Option A ruled out)
    • Stasis of blood flow - prolonged immobility, bed rest, long travel(Option C ruled out)
    • Hypercoagulability - inherited (e.g., Factor V Leiden) or acquired (e.g., malignancy, pregnancy, OCP use)(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is most frequently seen in Antiphospholipid Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hypercoagulability, leading to arterial/venous thrombosis, recurrent miscarriages, and thrombocytopenia.
  • The three most commonly associated antibodies in APS:
    • Lupus anticoagulant
    • Anticardiolipin antibody
    • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein I antibody
  • Among these, anti-beta 2 glycoprotein I antibody is highly specific and one of the most frequently detected in confirmed cases of APS.

Explanation of other options:

  • Beta 2 microglobulin antibody(Option A): Beta-2 microglobulin is a component of MHC class I molecules. Antibodies to it may be seen in certain renal diseases or lymphoproliferative disorders.
  • Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA)(Option B): It is Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases.
  • While APS can occur secondary to SLE, ANA is not specific to APS.
  • Anti-centromere antibody(Option C): Associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

questions.text: Warfarin skin necrosis is caused by?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Warfarin skin necrosis is a rare but serious complication that typically occurs within the first few days of initiating warfarin therapy.
  • Due to warfarin-induced rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with a pre-existing inherited protein C deficiency that results in a hypercoagulable state and thrombosis.
  • Not all heterozygous protein C-deficient patients receiving warfarin experience this complication, and not all patients with this complication have protein C deficiency

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

APLA (Option B): Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome leads to a hypercoagulable state with recurrent venous/arterial thrombosis and pregnancy losses, but it is not the mechanism behind warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Vitamin K deficiency (Option C): This causes decreased synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as Proteins C and S. While it can cause bleeding, it does not specifically lead to the paradoxical clotting and skin necrosis seen with warfarin initiation.

Fibrinogen deficiency (Option D): Also called afibrinogenemia, this results in defective fibrin clot formation and bleeding tendencies, not skin necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following liver-derived hormones plays a key role in the regulation of platelet production?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Thrombopoietin (TPO) is the principal physiologic regulator of platelet production. The liver secretes thrombopoietin at a constant rate into the circulation, where it binds to c-mpl ligands on both platelets and megakaryocytes.
  • Thrombopoietin bound to platelets are internalized and degraded and thrombopoietin bound to platelets stimulates platelet production.
  • In vitro, TPO induces the growth of colony-forming units-megakaryocyte (CFU-MK) and the generation of mature polyploid megakaryocytes, which subsequently form extended cytoplasmic processes, termed proplatelets.
  • Also Interleukin 6 (IL-6) stimulates megakaryocytopoiesis in the bone marrow, increasing platelet numbers in the circulation. IL-6 alone is poorly active on the growth of stem cell populations, but acts in synergy with stem cell factor (c-kit ligand) to expand the committed myeloid progenitor compartments but not the megakaryocyte progenitors.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Erythropoietin (Option A): Produced mainly by the kidneys (not liver), it regulates red blood cell production, not platelet production.

Thyroxin (Option C): Secreted by the thyroid gland, it controls basal metabolic rate and overall metabolism. It has no direct role in platelet regulation.

Gonadotropins (Option D): These are anterior pituitary hormones (LH, FSH) that regulate reproductive function. They are unrelated to platelet production.

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
The 25 year old patient presented with bleeding. The treating haematologist suspects the possibility of rare platelet disorder in which there is defect in granule release. Which of the following is /are disorder/s of granule release of platelets?
i Oculocutaneous albinism
ii Chediak-Higashi syndrome
iii Isolated dense granule deficiency
iv Gray platelet syndrome
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Platelet granule release disorders are a subset of platelet function disorders where platelets fail to release their intracellular granules (dense granules or alpha granules) during activation, leading to defective platelet aggregation and prolonged bleeding.
  • Most commonly, a decrease or absence of platelet dense granules is present. Platelet aggregation with ADP and epinephrine shows normal primary wave but absent or blunted secondary wave, and markedly reduced response to collagen.
  • These abnormalities result from lack of release of ADP from dense granules leading lack of secondary aggregation with ADP and epinephrine.
  • Chediak Higashi syndrome (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by easy bruising, oculocutaneous albinism and recurrent pyogenic infections.
  • Oculocutaneous Albinism is Seen in Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome (HPS). Associated with albinism, bleeding diathesis, and oculocutaneous hypopigmentation.
  • Isolated Dense Granule Deficiency in this condition, only platelet dense granules are reduced or absent. Platelet aggregation is impaired, especially with ADP and epinephrine. Leads to mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding.
  • Gray Platelet Syndrome is a rare alpha-granule deficiency in platelets. Platelets appear pale ("gray") on peripheral smear due to lack of alpha granules. Associated with mild bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and myelofibrosis in some cases.

choices.text: Caused by mutation in factor IX
Affects mainly males and heterozygous females

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Hemophilia A is the most common hereditary cause of serious bleeding. It is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by reduced factor VIII activity. It primarily affects males. Much less commonly, excessive bleeding occurs in heterozygous females, presumably due to preferential inactivation of the X chromosome carrying the normal factor VIII gene (unfavourable lyonization).
  • Approximately 30% of cases are caused by new mutations; in the remainder, there is a positive family history. Severe hemophilia A is observed in people with marked deficiencies of factor VIII (activity levels < 1% of normal). Milder deficiencies may only become apparent in the face of trauma or other hemostatic stresses. The varying degrees of factor VIII deficiency are explained by the existence of many different causative mutations, including deletions, inversions, and splice junction mutations.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Easy bruising
    • Massive hemorrhage after trauma or surgery
    • Spontaneous hemorrhages in high-stress tissues (especially joints)
    • → Leads to hemarthroses and progressive joint deformities
    • Petechiae absent
  • Specific assays for factor VIII are used to confirm the diagnosis of hemophilia A. Typically, patients with hemophilia A have a prolonged PTT that is corrected by mixing the patient's plasma with normal plasma. Specific factor assays are then used to confirm the deficiency of factor VIII.
  • In approximately 15% of those with severe hemophilia A, replacement therapy is complicated by the development of neutralizing antibodies against factor VIII, probably because factor VIII is seen by the immune system as a 'foreign' antigen. In these persons, the PTT fails to correct in mixing studies.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates warfarin oral anticoagulant therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • PT is the standard test for monitoring treatment with oral anticoagulant (warfarin) inhibiting carboxylation of vitamin K dependent factors (Factor II, VII, IX and X) and making these factors inactive.
  • In a patient receiving oral anticoagulants, PT should be reported as a ratio of PT of patient to PT of control, it should not be reported as percentage. Various types of thromboplastin reagents obtained from different sources (like ox brain, rabbit brain, rabbit lung) are available commercially for PT test.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

APTT (Option B): Activated partial thromboplastin time assesses the intrinsic and common pathways. It is used for monitoring unfractionated heparin therapy, not warfarin.

Bleeding time (Option C): Reflects platelet function and vascular integrity. It is unaffected by warfarin and not useful for monitoring anticoagulant therapy.

Thrombin time (Option D): Measures the final step of coagulation (conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin) and is prolonged in dysfibrinogenemia or with heparin therapy. It does not assess warfarin effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the component of dense granules of platelets?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Platelets are disc-shaped anucleate cell fragments that are shed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow into the bloodstream. Their function depends on several glycoprotein receptors, a contractile cytoskeleton, and two types of cytoplasmic granules.
  • α-Granules have the adhesion molecule P-selectin on their membranes and contain proteins involved in coagulation, such as fibrinogen, coagulation factor V, and vWF, as well as protein factors that may be involved in wound healing, such as fibronectin, platelet factor 4 (a heparin-binding chemokine), platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and transforming growth factor-β. Dense (or δ) granules contain adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate, ionized calcium, serotonin, and epinephrine.(Option A ,Option C and Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Skin haemorrhages are large and few

questions.text: Which of the following features does not align with typical presentations of coagulation disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Delayed bleeding is a hallmark of coagulation disorders, especially after trauma or surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following plays a key role in promoting vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Platelets attach to the exposed surface of endothelium following an endothelial injury, this adhesion is mediated by vWF which binds to GpIb receptors on platelets. This initiates activation of platelets, which change shape of platelets from a disc to sphere and release their contents to the exterior.
  • These are mainly adenosine diphosphate (ADP), serotonin and thromboxane A2. Platelet aggregation (sticking of platelets to each other) is mediated by thromboxane A2, collagen, ADP and thrombin.
  • Binding of ADP to platelets causes exposure of GpIIb/IIIa receptors which bind fibrinogen. Fibrinogen binding to multiple platelets causes formation of large platelets aggregates.

Explanation of other options:

  • Nitric Oxide (Option B): It is a Vasodilator and inhibits platelet aggregation.
  • Aspirin(Option C): Inhibits COX, thus reduces thromboxane A2, leading to inhibition of platelet aggregation.
  • PGE2(Option D): Generally inhibits platelet aggregation at low concentrations (though complex, not a primary aggregator).

questions.text: Match the following Disorders with the appropriate pattern seen on investigation
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Increased PT & APTT: In Advanced Liver Disease both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are affected due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors.
  • Increased APTT, Normal PT: In Hemophilia A, Factor VIII deficiency, part of the intrinsic pathway is affected thus there is a prolongation of the aPTT.
  • Normal APTT, Increased PT: In early Vitamin K Deficiency the Effect with vitamin K-dependent factors in the extrinsic pathway (Factor VII) prolongs the PT.
  • Normal APTT, Normal PT : Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) is a Platelet disorder without coagulation pathway defects.
  • Based on assays performed in clinical laboratories, the coagulation cascade has traditionally been divided into the extrinsic and intrinsic pathways.
  • The prothrombin time (PT) assay assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway (factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen). In brief, tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to plasma and the time for a fibrin clot to form is recorded.
  • The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway (factors XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen). In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negative charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.
